question: On his 35th birthday, I decided to tell Julius Benedict the truth about himself... It wasn't that he was the product of a scientific experiment. question: I was twelve and she was a nun -- that's real pressure. They both finish at the urinals and begin washing at the sink. I got to admit it, Jules -- since I met you, life is getting better all the time. Julius, a little smashed, can't hide his feelings. He grips Vince by the shoulders.
answer: For me, too, Vince! Sometimes I'm so happy, I want to pick you up and hug you! Julius starts to do so, just as another man enters.

question: How many of those... rules do you have?
answer: Quite a few. They were formulated by a Kendo swordsman in the 17th century, but their philosophical underpinnings can be applied to many other areas of life.

question: I bet. Uh... we got cable TV, a fully stocked bar, free ice -- we're in great shape.

question: I thought I'd just go and tuck Linda in for the night. Maybe read her a bedtime story. Don't wait up for me.

question: Oh yes it does. TIME CUT TO:
answer: sits watching the TV, nodding in amusement, laughing, slapping his knee in pleasure. You forgot your key -- I know. Lucky I waited up. Julius opens the door, revealing Marnie, who walks in right past him.

question: sits watching the TV, nodding in amusement, laughing, slapping his knee in pleasure. You forgot your key -- I know. Lucky I waited up. Julius opens the door, revealing Marnie, who walks in right past him.
answer: Hi -- Vince and Linda want to be * alone, so I'm afraid I'm going to stay here. Which bed should I take?

question: Either... I always sleep on the floor.
answer: Good night.

question: Good night. Julius puts the blanket and pillow from the other bed onto the floor between the two beds, then shuts off the other lamp. Silence...

question: Good night.
answer: This mattress is just as bad as the other one. This is better... Good night.

question: Good night. Are you cold?
answer: It's alright.

question: No, please, take my shirt. I'm * baking. Julius strips it off and hands it to her. She puts it on and pulls the blanket over her shoulder. Again she shivers. You still cold?

question: I know she will -- I have that effect on people -- -- One hundred and forty-three -- * one forty-four -- * -- I just hope she's not too disappointed in Julius -- he can't help how weird he seems at the start --

question: Hey -- I sleep great every night -- -- what if she's disappointed in me?

question: Five hundred. Don't want to overdo. He goes into her arms.

question: You're right. I couldn't do this without you, Linda.

question: I'm no good at playing house -- I'm grouchy in the morning, cranky in the afternoon, moody at night --

question: Why don't we sleep on this, okay? I mean, I've got a big day tomorrow. It's gonna be great -- taking my best girl to meet my mom.

question: There's nobody else, Linda, not anymore.

question: It's very beautiful, isn't it, Vince?

question: We'd like to see Miss Mary Anne Benedict, please.

question: Bull-shit. Julius, who's been quiet and distant throughout, suddenly intercedes.

question: hiding behind some machinery, scurries deeper into the bowels of the warehouse.

question: I am never going to forgive you for this.

question: You can be an irritating pain -- but sometimes you come in handy. -- Where'd you get the gun?

question: You got lucky. But your luck just ran out. A stream of gas is pouring out of the drums that Webster punctured whilst he was shooting at Vince. Webster smiles and backs off down the stream of gas, still holding out the cigarette. He stops at the very edge of the building. Well, I guess this is goodbye. answer: Wait a minute. Webster looks up. You've forgotten something. Webster grips the case tighter.

question: Duck. Suddenly the load hanging from the boom of a nearby crane smashes into Webster's back, and then dumps on him, burying him in rubble.
